overview: This subject builds on the work done in Contextual Studies 1 but with a deeper emphasis on the process of note choice within jazz/improvised music. The emphasis is still on the consolidation, reconstruction and manipulation of musical imagery within the brain of the improvising musician.
Students attend Languages of Music (lecture/workshop) which is supported by practical small group tutorials for each of the three areas of: harmonic, rhythmic and practical devices.
The assessment combines written examination and practical application.
intended learning outcomes: build and apply an understanding of the basic scales used in jazz improvisation;
apply knowledge of the principles underlying note selection in an harmonic environment;
sing, perform and transcribe vocal/instrumental examples from the improvised music canon;
identify and perform selected patterns and polyrhythms;
sing and perform selected harmonic and melodic structures;
apply basic keyboard technique to composition and accompanying.

assessments.description: Languages of Music - assessments: 4-minute practical presentation (10%), 200-word essay (5%), workbook (5 hours of work required) (5%). 20 hours (of work required)
Languages of Music written exam. 800 words (equivalent)
Three 4-minute in-class tests: Harmonic Devices; Rhythmic Devices; Practical Devises. 30 hours (of work required)
Three 4-minute practical exams: Harmonic Devices; Rhythmic Devices; Practical Devices. 30 hours (of work required)
Hurdle requirement:. Students must attend a minimum of 75% of all scheduled classes.

Semester 2.Contact hours: 51 hours, comprising one 2‐hour Languages of Music lecture/workshop, and three 45‐minute online practical tutorials per week.

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
